Body:
BC-BJT0910-SUNDAY-4THLEDE-COX 
    

      4TH UPDATE
      CoxNet Cox News Service budget
      FOR SUNDAY, Sept. 10, 2000
      c. 2000 Cox News Service

   For questions, please call 404-526-5456.

   Photo and graphics information and editors' names can be found
at the end of this budget.

   THE WEEKEND DUTY EDITORS ARE:

   IN ATLANTA: Diane Fall at 404-526-5456

   IN WASHINGTON: Andy Glass at 202-263-2389 (home).

   INTERNATIONAL

   MEXICO-HUMANRIGHTS MEXICO CITY _ Pressure is mounting for
Mexican President-elect Vicente Fox to look into Mexico's record of
human rights abuses. Prompted by the recent arrest of an Argentine
here suspected of torture in his home country, a group of people
with ``disappeared'' family members have resurrected their own
fight for justice. They accuse high-ranking officials of the
Institutional Revolutionary Party (PRI) of repressive acts over the
party's 71-year rule. Pressure is also on to review other cases _ a
peasant environmentalist and an Army colonel _ human rights group
believe are unjustly imprisoned now. (Ferriss, Cox News Service)
WITH PHOTOS. MOVED.

   RUSSIA-INTERNET MOSCOW _ Under a new law, every communications
and Internet provider in Russia must install a program designed by
the Federal Security Service, or FSB, to allow the intelligence
agency to monitor e-mail and Internet traffic by users. Not only
does the Internet provider have to allow the FSB access to their
network, but the companies have to pay for the installation and
training for these officers to do their dirty work. Human rights
organizations are up in arms, arguing it's a further sign that the
country has slipped back into a Soviet mode of control. (Coker, Cox
News Service) WITH PHOTOS. MOVED.

   ISRAEL-DEFENSE _ JERUSALEM _ In a country flush with military
bravado, it figures that Israeli tourist shops would offer an array
of army ball caps and fatigue T-shirts. ``America don't worry,''
quips one T-shirt around a drawing of an F-16 jet. ``Israel is
behind you.'' In truth, of course, it's the other way around.
American aid makes up about a quarter of Israel's defense budget,
including nearly half its equipment, comes free from America. But,
even as Israeli officials prepare to ask for increases in aid with
President Clinton's encouragement, some say that Israel's defense
dependence on American aid may be doing more harm than good.
(Kaplow, Cox News Service) PACKAGE MOVED.

   WAN: Location, Atlanta; Category, International; Subcategory,
Other.

   Expected to move in advance on the NYT Wire in both
International and Washington categories.

   Eds. Runs with ISRAEL-USAID; ISRAEL-DATA.

   WITH PHOTOS and a chart-graphic made available by The Palm Beach
Post.

   WITH

   ISRAEL-USAID _ TEL AVIV _ Israel, which has a per capita income
greater and Greece and Spain, receives some $3 billion from the
United States annually _ about a quarter of the total U.S. aid
budget. With a possible Mideast peace on the horizon, that figure
could grow by billions more over the next decade. But should it?
Analysts, officials and American Israel backers see the aid as an
investment that reaps priceless returns. A growing number of that
same group are beginning to question Israel's reliance on American
largesse, however. (Kaplow, Cox News Service)

   ISRAEL-DATA _ Information and stats on U.S. aid to Israel;
defense spending, etc.

   WAN: Location, Atlanta; Category, International; Subcategory,
Other.

   (Kaplow, Cox News Service)

   NATION

   CENSUS-ADJUST _ A federal lawsuit against the state of Virginia
is emerging as the all-important test case in the politically
charged issue of whether states next year can use raw census
results instead of statistically adjusted counts to redraw
legislative districts. A dozen major U.S. cities and counties have
joined the fight against a Virginia law passed this year by the
GOP-dominated legislature. Urban areas, with large minority
populations traditionally undercounted by the census, fear the
Virginia law will set a national precedent. (Holmes, Cox News
Service) MOVED.

   WAN: Atlanta, National, U.S. Government

   ANTITRUST-1STLD _ WASHINGTON _ Federal regulators who did not
stop the gigantic oil companies Exxon and Mobil from merging are
now picking on AOL and Time Warner, two companies that aren't even
in the same line of business. Why the scrutiny? The answer seems to
be that anti-trust regulators are shifting their efforts from
breaking up monopolies to making sure new ones don't get started.
(Geewax, Cox News Service)

   MOVED FRIDAY in (w) Washington and (f) financial categories.

   WAN: Atlanta, Business, Technology

   GRANDPARENTS _ WASHINGTON _ Remember gray-haired Grandma in her
checkered apron, baking perfect cookies? The new generation being
honored on Grandparents Day this Sunday includes a new crop of baby
boomers whose modern ideas and style defy the traditional
stereotypes. (Doyle, Cox News Service)

   MOVED FRIDAY in (w) Washington and (l) lifestyle categories.

   WAN: Atlanta, National, Other

   DEBATES _ WASHINGTON _ By rejecting the traditional presidential
debates, George W. Bush is making the same strategic error that
doomed his father's 1992 campaign, experts say: talking too much
about his opponent, and not enough about the voters. (Shepard,
Atlanta Journal-Constitution)

   MOVED in (w) Washington and (p) politics categories.

   WAN: Atlanta, National, Politics

   TECH-CAMPUS _ SANTA CLARA, Calif. _ When Sun Microsystems Inc.
started looking for space for a new office and corporate
headquarters here four years ago, it faced the same problems as any
company trying to expand in crowded Silicon Valley. Developable
land is scarce. Real estate prices are among the highest in the
world. And in environmentally conscious California, getting
regulatory approval for new projects isn't usually easy. Sun's
approach, however, was anything but typical. When the state put an
abandoned 112-year-old former mental hospital, decrepit and choked
by weeds, up for sale as surplus land, the computer giant bid on
the site and won. (Keefe, Cox News Service)

   With TECH-LIST _ Unusual features of the new campus.

   MOVED FRIDAY.

   The story and accompanying photos are also available on the
budget tool from Austin Business.

   LAW-SCHOOL _ WASHINGTON _ Wayne Reaud, a wealthy Texas trial
lawyer, tried to give Texas Tech University's law school $12.5
million. In the end, the university wouldn't take it _ and Reaud
thinks the reason is that Gov. George W. Bush or his supporters
couldn't stand the idea of the law school being named after one of
his ``enemies,'' a Democratic trial lawyer. But Chancellor John
Montford of Texas Tech, a former Democratic state senator, says it
was all a misunderstanding for which he was to blame, that his
intention all along was to name the law school building after
Reaud, not the school itself. The chairman of the university
regents, Jim Sowell of Dallas, said the university's policy is
clear: schools won't be named after someone for less than $25
million. (Hight, Cox News Service) MOVED.

   WAN: Atlanta, National, Other

   SLAUGHTER-HONORS _ ATLANTA _ J. C. Slaughter, 78, a black
veteran of World War II who won the purple heart and combat
infantry badge, was court martialed and dishonorably discharged
after he refused a direct order to return to the front lines.
Slaughter was seriously wounded and knew he'd be unable to keep up
with his unit. Recently, through his daughter's efforts, the Army
reopened Slaughter's case and exonerated him, giving him an
honorable discharge and veteran's benefits. (Davis, Atlanta
Journal-Constitution) MOVED.

   CHENEY _ WASHINGTON _ Cursory looks at Dick Cheney's voting
record reveal a very conservative record on certain social issues.
But examining his full record across a broad spectrum illustrates
he was even more of a voice in the wilderness. (Sherman, Atlanta
Journal-Constitution) MOVED.

   POL-TICKER _ A brief roundup of the day's campaign events,
pulled from Cox staff and wire reports. (Cox News Service) ETA: 9
p.m.

   OPED/EDITORIAL

   JOEMURRAY-COLUMN _ LUFKIN, Texas _ Will Rogers said he wasn't a
member of any organized political party _ he was a Democrat. After
this past week, you could say the same about being a Republican.
(Murray, Cox News Service) MOVED.

   TEEPEN-COLUMN _ George W. Bush is back in full-smirk mode now
that he's muddled the issue over presidential campaign debates. He
appears to think he has muddled it successfully, and perhaps he
has. Didn't Al Gore say he would debate Bush any time anywhere and
isn't he now, just as Bush charges, refusing to do just that?
Indeed. But Gore's rhetorical sally assumed Bush would first buy
into the debates that the presidential debate commission would set
up. After all, every candidate since 1988 had, including daddy
Bush. (Tom Teepen is national correspondent for Cox Newspapers.)
MOVED THURSDAY.

   KLEINBERG-COLUMN _ All along I knew that Patty the Postal Lady
was not a latent killer. Patty delivers the mail to my house.
Often, we chat. Sometimes about the rock music she has bellowing
from the portable radio in her little truck, sometimes about other
things. But I never envisioned that one troubled day she would show
up back at the post office, automatic weapon in hand, and
rat-a-tat-tat a bunch of co-workers. (Kleinberg, Cox News Service.)
MOVED THURSDAY.

   GLASS-COLUMN _ (Andy Glass is a columnist for Cox News Service
in the Washington bureau.) MOVES THURSDAY.

   LIFESTYLE

   ATTENTION EDITORS:

   DAYTON END OF LIFE SERIES

   Beginning Sunday, the Dayton Daily News begins a five-part
series called ``Letting Go: Choices at the end of life.'' It's all
about end-of-life issues, from hospice care to talking to doctors
and families, support groups and health industry issues. The series
is running in conjunction with a PBS Series by Bill Moyers called
``On Our Terms'' that is running in most markets from Sunday, Sept.
10 through Wednesday Sept. 13, but the stories can stand alone. The
stories will be available via the Budget Tool with a run date that
corresponds to the day the story is moving. Elements from the
series will be used for the CoxNet HEALTHY LIVING page for Tuesday,
Sept, 19. That page will be available on Friday, Sept. 15 at 2 p.m.

   Series stories include:

   SUNDAY, SEPT. 10

   END-LETTINGGO _ DAYTON, Ohio _ Scene-setter for the series. 17
inches (Lamb, Dayton Daily News)

   WITH

   END-OF-LIFE _ DAYTON, Ohio _ The morning after Chuck Gross's
90th birthday bash, he woke up with severe chest pain from a
fracture in his spine. His doctor guessed it had been caused by the
spread of his prostate cancer, first diagnosed eight years before.
But Gross declined to be treated or even tested for metastatic
disease. He felt the time had come to leave this life gracefully,
and on his own terms. (Lamb, Dayton Daily News) 80 inches. WITH
PHOTOS

   WITH

   END-PBS _ DAYTON, Ohio _ Beginning at 9 p.m. CT Sunday and
continuing at 9 p.m. CT Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday, WPTD,
Channel 16, will air On Our Own Terms: Moyers on Dying. This PBS
series by Bill and Judith Davidson Moyers examines the options
available for the terminally ill. The series will be repeated at
various times throughout the week. Each part focuses on different
topics. (Dayton Daily News)

   WITH

   END-OF-LIFE-SIDE _ DAYTON, Ohio _ An incredibly complete list of
resources (organizations, books, videos, etc.) (DeBrosse, Dayton
Daily News) 35 inches.

   All stories MOVED FRIDAY in (l) lifestyles category.

   MONDAY, SEPT. 11

   END-DYING _ DAYTON, Ohio _ The cost of dying. Trying to keep
people alive in the last months of life is bankrupting our health
care system as scientific advances outpace our ability to pay for
them. But the alternative of allocating what we do and don't pay
for raises lots of thorny ethical issues. Local health care
organizations have put together a consortium of ethicists to
address these problems, and we talk to them about a number of
issues. (Lamb, Dayton Daily News) 45 to 50 inches. WITH PHOTO

   END-DIRECTIVES _ DAYTON, Ohio _ Living wills, advance
directives, durable powers of attorney. What are they and what do
you need to be doing to make sure your wishes about dying are
followed. (Lamb, Dayton Daily News) 15 inches

   END-SERIES _ DAYTON, Ohio _ Short story explaining the Bill
Moyers' series, with a how to watch box. (Dayton Daily News)

   END-SERIESBOX _ DAYTON, Ohio _ Feature about the series, what's
coming up. (Dayton Daily News) MOVED FRIDAY.

   TUESDAY, SEPT. 12

   END-DRDEATH _ DAYTON, Ohio _ Doctors are trained to prevent
death, not cooperate with it. The result is that they're at
cross-purposes with hospice care. By overestimating life
expectancies, they both mislead patients and families and disable
the hospice concept. It's generally agreed that doctors need more
training in end-of life care, particularly the pain-relief and
psychological aspects, but aside from that, there is an honest
dispute as to where doctors belong on the spectrum from defying
death to embracing hospice care. (Lamb, Dayton Daily News) 50
inches

   WITH PHOTOS

   END-SERIES _ DAYTON, Ohio _ Short story explaining the Bill
Moyers' series, with a how to watch box. (Dayton Daily News)

   END-SERIESBOX _ DAYTON, Ohio _ Furniture about the series,
what's coming up. (Dayton Daily News)

   END-CHILDRENS _ DAYTON, Ohio _ The Children's Medical Center has
a hospice-type program for the families of dying children. (Lamb,
Dayton Daily News) 30 inches. WITH PHOTOS

   END-INPATIENT _ DAYTON, Ohio _ Hospice care for patients in the
hospital range from Miami Valley's palliative care program to
arrangements that other hospitals have with Hospice of Dayton.
(Lamb, Dayton Daily News) Less than 10 inches.

   END-LAMB _ DAYTON, Ohio _ Column about some ethical issue(s)
generated from reporting on this series. Perhaps: Assisted suicide,
or Is there even such thing as a ``dignified'' or ``good'' death or
is this another case of the boomer generation trying to control
something beyond its control? (Lamb, Dayton Daily News) 20 inches

   WEDNESDAY, SEPT. 13

   END-MONEYSTRAIN _ DAYTON, Ohio _ Doctors didn't discover Sandra
Lee Hughes' lung cancer until the disease had reached her brain and
paralyzed her legs. At 43, and with two young daughters in her
care, Hughes suddenly had no job and no family support system at a
time when she was facing a terminal disease. She called on her
estranged husband, an unemployed Fairborn resident from whom she
had been separated for six years. He moved her from Alabama to his
home in Fairborn, where family members, including Hughes'
14-year-old daughter, Jennifer, took turns caring for her in a
tiny, ramshackle house. For hours at a time, Jennifer found herself
alone with her mother and, at times, no food to eat. A family
doctor recommended Hospice of Dayton, and soon the agency's home
health aides were there not only to care for Hughes but to make
sure there was enough medical supplies and food in the home.
Hospice never charged the family a penny, but the agency must rely
on donations from the community to help families like Sandra's.
Once she saw that her daughters would be taken care of, Hughes
decided to let go, calling out to Jennifer one night to say
``goodbye.'' (DeBrosse, Dayton Daily News) 25 inches

   WITH PHOTO

   WITH

   END-MONEYSTRAINSIDE _ DAYTON, Ohio _ Tips on how to ease the
financial strain and utilize community resources for families
dealing with the death of a loved one. (DeBrosse, Dayton Daily
News) 10 inches

   WITH

   END-VETS _ DAYTON, Ohio _ Harold Johnson served his country
proudly in Vietnam as an infantry sergeant, only to be exposed by
his own government to a toxic chemical, Agent Orange, that years
later would lead to lung cancer. Johnson, 51, is now in the end
stages of that disease. He says he's no longer bitter about what
happened to him in Vietnam, and that he looks forward to ``meeting
the Lord.'' And he's also grateful to the hospice and palliative
care program at the Dayton VA, which has provided his end-of-life
care free of charge. The VA here wants to get the word out: it
provides a wide array of end-of-life services to eligible veterans,
and at no cost. (DeBrosse, Dayton Daily News) 25 inches. WITH PHOTO

   WITH

   END-PBSSERIES _ DAYTON, Ohio _ Short story explaining the Bill
Moyers'' series, with a how to watch box. (Dayton Daily News)

   WITH

   SERIESBOX _ DAYTON, Ohio _ Furniture about the series, what is
coming up. (Dayton Daily News) Brief.

   THURSDAY, SEPT. 14

   END-CAROL _ DAYTON, Ohio _ Wes Hills first-person story about
his wife Carol's illness and death. (Hill, Dayton Daily News) WITH
PHOTO 115 inches

   WITH

   END-SERIESBOX _ DAYTON, Ohio _ Items about the series. (Dayton
Daily News)

   END OF SERIES

   CHILDREN OF THE CIVIL RIGHTS MOVEMENT PACKAGE

   ATTENTION EDITORS: Atlanta Journal Constitution reporter John
Blake has interviewed several men and women about growing up in the
1950s and '60s as children of the civil rights movement. The people
at the center of the struggle led dramatic, often dangerous, lives.
So, too, did their kids. The children of the movement _ the
offspring of black militants, nonviolent activists and even
segregationist leaders _ are now adults. They have followed many
roads in recent years. Some continue to carry on their parents'
work. Others want only to forget their childhood. Blake profiled
nine of them.

   The story is embargoed until Sunday, Sept. 10, but will move by
Friday evening. PHOTOS are available.

   Stories include:

   CIVILRIGHTS-CHILDREN _ Ericka Brown-Abram thinks she had a
typical childhood. Her mother's friends were killed in police
shootouts. Her family lived under FBI surveillance. She was
constantly shadowed by a bodyguard, even when she ran after the
neighborhood ice cream truck. Brown, 30, the daughter of a Black
Panther Party leader, once thought there was nothing unusual about
growing up in a communal home and attending a grade school where
students read Mao Tse-Tung's Red Book. ``A lot of people had this
swashbuckling idea of the Panthers,'' she said. ``But when you're a
child it all seemed normal.'' Nothing was normal, though, about
growing up in the 1950s and '60s as a child of the civil rights
movement. The people at the center of the struggle led dramatic,
often dangerous, lives. So, too, did their kids. These children of
the movement _ the offspring of black militants, nonviolent
activists and even segregationist leaders _ are now adults. The
Children of the Movement have followed many roads in recent years.
Some continue to carry on their parents' work. Others want only to
forget their childhood. Here are the stories of eight of them.
(Blake, Atlanta Journal-Constitution) 110 inches. WITH PHOTOS.
MOVED FRIDAY.

   WITH THE FOLLOWING PROFILES:

   _ Ericka Brown-Abram _ Daughter of Black Panther Elaine Brown.

   _ Albert Vivian _ Son of Rev. C.T. Vivian, a leader in the
Southern Christian Leadership Conference.

   _ Peggy Wallace _ Daughter of the late Alabama Gov. George
Wallace.

   _ Warith Deen Mohammed _ Son of Elijah Muhammed Sr., leader of
the Nation of Islam.

   Chevara Orrin and Bacardi Jackson _ Daughters of Rev. James
Bevel, a key aide to the Rev. Martin Luther King, Jr.

   Ross Barnett Jr. _ son of Mississippi Gov. Ross Barnett, a
dedicated segregationist.

   END OF PACKAGE

   DIGITAL-CAM _ DAYTON, Ohio _ The first digital still photograph
cameras hit the consumer market a few years ago and digital
camcorders followed more recently. Now it's possible to have two
digital cameras in one. JVC Co. of America has a line of what it
calls Digital DualCams that can record moving video with sound and
still photographs at the same time. (Cummings, Dayton Daily News)
WITH PHOTO. MOVED FRIDAY.

   RADIO _ Once upon a time, the radio was the most important piece
of furniture in most American living rooms. Now those vintage
Crosleys, Zeniths and Atwater Kents that brought us such shows as
Fibber McGee & Molly, Gangbusters and The Lone Ranger are among the
nation's hottest collectibles. (Dayton Daily News) WITH PHOTOS.
MOVED FRIDAY.

   WINE-MAKERS _ GRAND JUNCTION, Colo. _ hat's the biggest myth
when it comes to winemakers? They still stomp grapes with their
feet like the famous episode with Lucille Ball. (Grand Junction
Daily Sentinel) WITH PHOTO. MOVED FRIDAY.

   GLOBAL-WARMING _ Arctic sea ice has thinned by 40 percent in the
last 30 years. This summer, there was open water at the North Pole.
From the Andes to the Alps, mountain glaciers are retreating. And
across North America, from the fire-scorched West to the
drought-parched Southeast, the last year of the millennium has
given millions a summer of discontent. As the signs of a warmer
world grow more apparent, there are some nagging new questions
about ways to prevent it. A new analysis by NASA physicist James
Hansen, one of the first scientists to sound the alarm over global
warming 20 years ago, suggests that industrialized nations
struggling to implement a reduction in carbon dioxide emissions
called for under the proposed 1997 Kyoto Protocol, may be pursuing
the wrong villains in the global greenhouse mystery. (Toner,
Atlanta Journal-Constitution) MOVED FRIDAY.

   ARMY-JOURNALIST _ At a party for his Sunday school class, Jim
McLaughlin decided to play a trivia game, asking his two dozen
guests to jot down something the others didn't know about them. On
his own slip of paper, McLaughlin wrote: ``I did what Gore did in
Vietnam.'' The crowd was stumped. Now, with Al Gore's campaign
publicizing his Vietnam service, the group would probably be able
to guess what McLaughlin meant: He, like Gore, served as an
enlisted Army journalist. (Hendrick, Atlanta Journal-Constitution)
WITH PHOTOS. MOVED FRIDAY.

   TRAVEL

   COXNET TRAVEL _ (EDS: This is the CoxNet Travel page for the
current week. This layout is now available.)

   FAT-CRUISE _ Fighting the battle of the bulge onboard: ``Take
two pairs of pants,'' friends who are cruise veterans advised when
they found out about my plans for a seven-day Caribbean voyage. A
pair you can wear now and one the next size up for after I'd
crossed the sea of indulgence, they said. No way, I replied. Weigh,
they said. Weigh before you go. Weigh after you come back. You'll
be five pounds heavier. And I thought you were supposed to leave
your cares behind on a cruise. Would this be the diary of a
disaster at sea? (AMiller, Atlanta Journal-Constitution) WITH
ILLUSTRATION. MOVED FRIDAY.

   CRUISE-EXPERT _ Three metro Atlanta cruising experts suggest the
best cruises for different types of travelers _ families,
romance-minded, seniors, adventurers, budget-minded. Also,
suggestions of interesting specialty cruises. (Hamilton, Atlanta
Journal-Constitution) MOVED FRIDAY.

   CRUISE-GOING _ Weekly column by Paula Crouch Thrasher of news,
notes and tips. This week: Lots and lots of notes related to
cruises. (Thrasher, Atlanta Journal-Constitution) WITH PHOTOS.
MOVED FRIDAY.

   HOT-ARIZONA _ The first thing that hits you about Phoenix is the
heat. Yes, it's dry heat, whatever that means, but 113 degrees _
the high during a recent trip _ is still hot by any standard. But
there's some good news. The temperatures will soon start to get
cooler, travelers will look for an interesting place to go, and
Phoenix is a nice, affordable destination with more than enough to
do. (Marcano, Dayton Daily News)

   COXNET LIFESTYLES _ (EDS: This is the CoxNet Lifestyles page for
the current week. This layout is now available.)

   COXNET LIFESTYLES 0909: FALL MOVIE PREVIEW: You'd think it was
the turn of the millennium. At least a dozen movies coming this
fall deal with a dark stranger (could it be Satan?), supernatural
oddities or unnatural bloodsuckers. After the box office success
achieved by ``The Sixth Sense'' and ``The Blair Witch Project,''
everybody's lining up to cash in. (Longino, Atlanta
Journal-Constitution) Art includes a 3-column color photo of Jim
Carrey as ``The Grinch,'' a 2-column color photo from the film
``Almost Famous,'' a 18-pica color photo from the film ``The
Contender,'' and a 2-column color photo from the film ``The Legend
of Bagger Vance.''

   END OF PAGE

   FASHION

   AJC's FALL 2000 PREVIEW

   FASHION-DCOM _ Dressing up's back in style as some of Atlanta's
most fashionable dot-commers demonstrate while modeling fall
styles. (Walton, Atlanta Journal-Constitution) MOVED FRIDAY.

   GOLD _ Fashion editor A. Scott Walton extols the virtues of all
things gold in apparel and accessories as we enter the fall fashion
season. (Walton, Atlanta Journal-Constitution) MOVED FRIDAY.

   GOTTAHAVE _ In which we detail must have clothes and accessories
for the fall fashion season. (Johnson, Atlanta
Journal-Constitution) MOVED FRIDAY.

   MAKEUP _ Glamour's returned, so cosmetics are more vibrant and
feminine than in recent years. (Hill, Atlanta Journal-Constitution)
MOVED FRIDAY.

   ENTERTAINMENT/ARTS

   CATS-18YEARS _ Interview with woman who has played on Cats for
18 years. (Erstein, Palm Beach Post) WITH PHOTO. MOVED FRIDAY.

   On Sunday evening, millions of television viewers will tune in
to watch the ``52nd Annual Prime-time Emmy Awards.'' The Academy of
Television Arts and Sciences will hand out winged statuettes in 27
categories to TV's best and brightest. Cox newspapers will have
TV's biggest night covered. There will be stories available
previewing the Emmys from The Atlanta Journal-Constitution, the
Palm Beach Post and the Austin American-Statesman. The Dayton Daily
News will provide live coverage of the broadcast and make a story
available after the show.

   All of the following Emmy stories will be available via the
Budget Tool.

   Any questions, call CoxNet at 404-526-5456

   PALM BEACH POST EMMY PACKAGE:

   FOR SUNDAY

   EMMY-MAIN _ A complete preview and predictions. (Thompson, Palm
Beach Post) 40 inches

   WITH

   EMMY-QA _ A question and answer session with one of the Ernst
and Young accountants. WITH MUG (Thompson, Palm Beach Post) 15
inches

   EMMY-MOMENT - Key Emmy speeches and moments. Brief. (Palm Beach
Post)

   FROM THE AJC

   EMMYS _ An analytical look at tonight's (9/10) Emmys. Is it
Sopranos vs. West Wing? Will & Grace v. the old guard? (Kloer,
Atlanta Journal-Constitution)

   FROM DAYTON

   The Dayton Daily news is planning two, possibly three, live
stories on the Emmy telecast. The stories, written from Dayton,
will be available on the the Budget Tool.

   Stories include:

   EMMY-SHOW _ A wrap-up of the Emmy telecast. (Dempsey, Dayton
Daily News) MOVING AFTER THE SHOW.

   WITH

   EMMY-SIDE _ What was seen, heard at the Emmys. Tidbits and notes
from the show. (Dempsey, Dayton Daily News)

   WESTWING _ This is a tentative story to be written if West Wing
captures several Emmys. Actors Martin Sheen, Rob Lowe and Allison
Janney has ties to Dayton. (Dempsey, Dayton Daily News) TENTATIVE.

   FROM AUSTIN

   EMMY0910 _ We predict who is going to take home the gold.
(Holloway, Austin American-Statesman) 35 inches

   END OF EMMY COVERAGE

   MOVIES

   CROWE _ Interview with writer-director Cameron Crowe (''Jerry
Maguire''), whose latest movie ``Almost Famous'' is an
autobiographical movie that fictionalizes his own experience, as a
15-year-old precocious journalist, going on the road with an
upcoming band to write a piece for Rolling Stone. (Murray, Atlanta
Journal-Constitution) MOVED FRIDAY.

   MUSIC

   LORETTA-LYNN _ Profile of Loretta Lynn, from her Nashville dude
ranch/home, right before her annual homecoming show. Her new album
comes out Sept. 12, and a second autobiography is due as well.
(Longino, Atlanta Journal-Constitution) MOVED FRIDAY.

   WEBRADIO _ iTurf is a Web site aimed at teens. The company that
runs the site has launched a new radio component that is live
weekdays from 1 p.m.-1 a.m., with a chat function that hooks up
listeners to each other and the DJ. Listeners can discuss the music
as it plays. Along with Soundbreak.com and a couple of other sites,
this represents a growing trend in live, DJ-hosted Internet-only
radio. (Drennen, Atlanta Journal-Constitution) MOVED FRIDAY.

   BOOKS

   COXNET BOOKS _ (EDS: This is the CoxNet Books page for the
current week. This layout is now available.)

   BOOKS _BACH _ Johann Sebastian Bach, a biography by Christoph
Wolff, reviewed by Michael Barnes. (Barnes, Austin
American-Statesman)

   BOOKS-THUNDER _ Thunder from the East: Portrait of a Rising Asia
by Nicholas Kristof and Sheryl WuDunn, reviewed by Joe Albright,
former Cox correspondent in China. (Albright, Austin
American-Statesman)

   SKUBE-ON-BOOKS _ (Skube, Atlanta Journal-Constitution) MOVED
FRIDAY.

   REVIEW_ELMORE _ DDN review of Pagan Babies, the new thriller by
Elmore Leonard. (Dayton Daily News)

   OLY-ARCH _ Tom Archdeacon column on Dayton track star Tonja
Buford-Bailey, a three-time Olympian who is a medal favorite for
the Sydney games. Her best event is the 400 meter dash.
(Archdeacon, Dayton Daily News)

   For Use By Clients of the New York Times News Service
Text:
For questions, please call 404-526-5456.

   Photo and graphics information and editors' names can be found
at the end of this budget.

   THE WEEKEND DUTY EDITORS ARE:

   IN ATLANTA: Diane Fall at 404-526-5456

   IN WASHINGTON: Andy Glass at 202-263-2389 (home).

   INTERNATIONAL

   MEXICO-HUMANRIGHTS MEXICO CITY _ Pressure is mounting for
Mexican President-elect Vicente Fox to look into Mexico's record of
human rights abuses. Prompted by the recent arrest of an Argentine
here suspected of torture in his home country, a group of people
with ``disappeared'' family members have resurrected their own
fight for justice. They accuse high-ranking officials of the
Institutional Revolutionary Party (PRI) of repressive acts over the
party's 71-year rule. Pressure is also on to review other cases _ a
peasant environmentalist and an Army colonel _ human rights group
believe are unjustly imprisoned now. (Ferriss, Cox News Service)
WITH PHOTOS. MOVED.

   RUSSIA-INTERNET MOSCOW _ Under a new law, every communications
and Internet provider in Russia must install a program designed by
the Federal Security Service, or FSB, to allow the intelligence
agency to monitor e-mail and Internet traffic by users. Not only
does the Internet provider have to allow the FSB access to their
network, but the companies have to pay for the installation and
training for these officers to do their dirty work. Human rights
organizations are up in arms, arguing it's a further sign that the
country has slipped back into a Soviet mode of control. (Coker, Cox
News Service) WITH PHOTOS. MOVED.

   ISRAEL-DEFENSE _ JERUSALEM _ In a country flush with military
bravado, it figures that Israeli tourist shops would offer an array
of army ball caps and fatigue T-shirts. ``America don't worry,''
quips one T-shirt around a drawing of an F-16 jet. ``Israel is
behind you.'' In truth, of course, it's the other way around.
American aid makes up about a quarter of Israel's defense budget,
including nearly half its equipment, comes free from America. But,
even as Israeli officials prepare to ask for increases in aid with
President Clinton's encouragement, some say that Israel's defense
dependence on American aid may be doing more harm than good.
(Kaplow, Cox News Service) PACKAGE MOVED.

   WAN: Location, Atlanta; Category, International; Subcategory,
Other.

   Expected to move in advance on the NYT Wire in both
International and Washington categories.

   Eds. Runs with ISRAEL-USAID; ISRAEL-DATA.

   WITH PHOTOS and a chart-graphic made available by The Palm Beach
Post.

   WITH

   ISRAEL-USAID _ TEL AVIV _ Israel, which has a per capita income
greater and Greece and Spain, receives some $3 billion from the
United States annually _ about a quarter of the total U.S. aid
budget. With a possible Mideast peace on the horizon, that figure
could grow by billions more over the next decade. But should it?
Analysts, officials and American Israel backers see the aid as an
investment that reaps priceless returns. A growing number of that
same group are beginning to question Israel's reliance on American
largesse, however. (Kaplow, Cox News Service)

   ISRAEL-DATA _ Information and stats on U.S. aid to Israel;
defense spending, etc.

   WAN: Location, Atlanta; Category, International; Subcategory,
Other.

   (Kaplow, Cox News Service)

   NATION

   CENSUS-ADJUST _ A federal lawsuit against the state of Virginia
is emerging as the all-important test case in the politically
charged issue of whether states next year can use raw census
results instead of statistically adjusted counts to redraw
legislative districts. A dozen major U.S. cities and counties have
joined the fight against a Virginia law passed this year by the
GOP-dominated legislature. Urban areas, with large minority
populations traditionally undercounted by the census, fear the
Virginia law will set a national precedent. (Holmes, Cox News
Service) MOVED.

   WAN: Atlanta, National, U.S. Government

   ANTITRUST-1STLD _ WASHINGTON _ Federal regulators who did not
stop the gigantic oil companies Exxon and Mobil from merging are
now picking on AOL and Time Warner, two companies that aren't even
in the same line of business. Why the scrutiny? The answer seems to
be that anti-trust regulators are shifting their efforts from
breaking up monopolies to making sure new ones don't get started.
(Geewax, Cox News Service)

   MOVED FRIDAY in (w) Washington and (f) financial categories.

   WAN: Atlanta, Business, Technology

   GRANDPARENTS _ WASHINGTON _ Remember gray-haired Grandma in her
checkered apron, baking perfect cookies? The new generation being
honored on Grandparents Day this Sunday includes a new crop of baby
boomers whose modern ideas and style defy the traditional
stereotypes. (Doyle, Cox News Service)

   MOVED FRIDAY in (w) Washington and (l) lifestyle categories.

   WAN: Atlanta, National, Other

   DEBATES _ WASHINGTON _ By rejecting the traditional presidential
debates, George W. Bush is making the same strategic error that
doomed his father's 1992 campaign, experts say: talking too much
about his opponent, and not enough about the voters. (Shepard,
Atlanta Journal-Constitution)

   MOVED in (w) Washington and (p) politics categories.

   WAN: Atlanta, National, Politics

   TECH-CAMPUS _ SANTA CLARA, Calif. _ When Sun Microsystems Inc.
started looking for space for a new office and corporate
headquarters here four years ago, it faced the same problems as any
company trying to expand in crowded Silicon Valley. Developable
land is scarce. Real estate prices are among the highest in the
world. And in environmentally conscious California, getting
regulatory approval for new projects isn't usually easy. Sun's
approach, however, was anything but typical. When the state put an
abandoned 112-year-old former mental hospital, decrepit and choked
by weeds, up for sale as surplus land, the computer giant bid on
the site and won. (Keefe, Cox News Service)

   With TECH-LIST _ Unusual features of the new campus.

   MOVED FRIDAY.

   The story and accompanying photos are also available on the
budget tool from Austin Business.

   LAW-SCHOOL _ WASHINGTON _ Wayne Reaud, a wealthy Texas trial
lawyer, tried to give Texas Tech University's law school $12.5
million. In the end, the university wouldn't take it _ and Reaud
thinks the reason is that Gov. George W. Bush or his supporters
couldn't stand the idea of the law school being named after one of
his ``enemies,'' a Democratic trial lawyer. But Chancellor John
Montford of Texas Tech, a former Democratic state senator, says it
was all a misunderstanding for which he was to blame, that his
intention all along was to name the law school building after
Reaud, not the school itself. The chairman of the university
regents, Jim Sowell of Dallas, said the university's policy is
clear: schools won't be named after someone for less than $25
million. (Hight, Cox News Service) MOVED.

   WAN: Atlanta, National, Other

   SLAUGHTER-HONORS _ ATLANTA _ J. C. Slaughter, 78, a black
veteran of World War II who won the purple heart and combat
infantry badge, was court martialed and dishonorably discharged
after he refused a direct order to return to the front lines.
Slaughter was seriously wounded and knew he'd be unable to keep up
with his unit. Recently, through his daughter's efforts, the Army
reopened Slaughter's case and exonerated him, giving him an
honorable discharge and veteran's benefits. (Davis, Atlanta
Journal-Constitution) MOVED.

   CHENEY _ WASHINGTON _ Cursory looks at Dick Cheney's voting
record reveal a very conservative record on certain social issues.
But examining his full record across a broad spectrum illustrates
he was even more of a voice in the wilderness. (Sherman, Atlanta
Journal-Constitution) MOVED.

   POL-TICKER _ A brief roundup of the day's campaign events,
pulled from Cox staff and wire reports. (Cox News Service) ETA: 9
p.m.

   OPED/EDITORIAL

   JOEMURRAY-COLUMN _ LUFKIN, Texas _ Will Rogers said he wasn't a
member of any organized political party _ he was a Democrat. After
this past week, you could say the same about being a Republican.
(Murray, Cox News Service) MOVED.

   TEEPEN-COLUMN _ George W. Bush is back in full-smirk mode now
that he's muddled the issue over presidential campaign debates. He
appears to think he has muddled it successfully, and perhaps he
has. Didn't Al Gore say he would debate Bush any time anywhere and
isn't he now, just as Bush charges, refusing to do just that?
Indeed. But Gore's rhetorical sally assumed Bush would first buy
into the debates that the presidential debate commission would set
up. After all, every candidate since 1988 had, including daddy
Bush. (Tom Teepen is national correspondent for Cox Newspapers.)
MOVED THURSDAY.

   KLEINBERG-COLUMN _ All along I knew that Patty the Postal Lady
was not a latent killer. Patty delivers the mail to my house.
Often, we chat. Sometimes about the rock music she has bellowing
from the portable radio in her little truck, sometimes about other
things. But I never envisioned that one troubled day she would show
up back at the post office, automatic weapon in hand, and
rat-a-tat-tat a bunch of co-workers. (Kleinberg, Cox News Service.)
MOVED THURSDAY.

   GLASS-COLUMN _ (Andy Glass is a columnist for Cox News Service
in the Washington bureau.) MOVES THURSDAY.

   LIFESTYLE

   ATTENTION EDITORS:

   DAYTON END OF LIFE SERIES

   Beginning Sunday, the Dayton Daily News begins a five-part
series called ``Letting Go: Choices at the end of life.'' It's all
about end-of-life issues, from hospice care to talking to doctors
and families, support groups and health industry issues. The series
is running in conjunction with a PBS Series by Bill Moyers called
``On Our Terms'' that is running in most markets from Sunday, Sept.
10 through Wednesday Sept. 13, but the stories can stand alone. The
stories will be available via the Budget Tool with a run date that
corresponds to the day the story is moving. Elements from the
series will be used for the CoxNet HEALTHY LIVING page for Tuesday,
Sept, 19. That page will be available on Friday, Sept. 15 at 2 p.m.

   Series stories include:

   SUNDAY, SEPT. 10

   END-LETTINGGO _ DAYTON, Ohio _ Scene-setter for the series. 17
inches (Lamb, Dayton Daily News)

   WITH

   END-OF-LIFE _ DAYTON, Ohio _ The morning after Chuck Gross's
90th birthday bash, he woke up with severe chest pain from a
fracture in his spine. His doctor guessed it had been caused by the
spread of his prostate cancer, first diagnosed eight years before.
But Gross declined to be treated or even tested for metastatic
disease. He felt the time had come to leave this life gracefully,
and on his own terms. (Lamb, Dayton Daily News) 80 inches. WITH
PHOTOS

   WITH

   END-PBS _ DAYTON, Ohio _ Beginning at 9 p.m. CT Sunday and
continuing at 9 p.m. CT Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday, WPTD,
Channel 16, will air On Our Own Terms: Moyers on Dying. This PBS
series by Bill and Judith Davidson Moyers examines the options
available for the terminally ill. The series will be repeated at
various times throughout the week. Each part focuses on different
topics. (Dayton Daily News)

   WITH

   END-OF-LIFE-SIDE _ DAYTON, Ohio _ An incredibly complete list of
resources (organizations, books, videos, etc.) (DeBrosse, Dayton
Daily News) 35 inches.

   All stories MOVED FRIDAY in (l) lifestyles category.

   MONDAY, SEPT. 11

   END-DYING _ DAYTON, Ohio _ The cost of dying. Trying to keep
people alive in the last months of life is bankrupting our health
care system as scientific advances outpace our ability to pay for
them. But the alternative of allocating what we do and don't pay
for raises lots of thorny ethical issues. Local health care
organizations have put together a consortium of ethicists to
address these problems, and we talk to them about a number of
issues. (Lamb, Dayton Daily News) 45 to 50 inches. WITH PHOTO

   END-DIRECTIVES _ DAYTON, Ohio _ Living wills, advance
directives, durable powers of attorney. What are they and what do
you need to be doing to make sure your wishes about dying are
followed. (Lamb, Dayton Daily News) 15 inches

   END-SERIES _ DAYTON, Ohio _ Short story explaining the Bill
Moyers' series, with a how to watch box. (Dayton Daily News)

   END-SERIESBOX _ DAYTON, Ohio _ Feature about the series, what's
coming up. (Dayton Daily News) MOVED FRIDAY.

   TUESDAY, SEPT. 12

   END-DRDEATH _ DAYTON, Ohio _ Doctors are trained to prevent
death, not cooperate with it. The result is that they're at
cross-purposes with hospice care. By overestimating life
expectancies, they both mislead patients and families and disable
the hospice concept. It's generally agreed that doctors need more
training in end-of life care, particularly the pain-relief and
psychological aspects, but aside from that, there is an honest
dispute as to where doctors belong on the spectrum from defying
death to embracing hospice care. (Lamb, Dayton Daily News) 50
inches

   WITH PHOTOS

   END-SERIES _ DAYTON, Ohio _ Short story explaining the Bill
Moyers' series, with a how to watch box. (Dayton Daily News)

   END-SERIESBOX _ DAYTON, Ohio _ Furniture about the series,
what's coming up. (Dayton Daily News)

   END-CHILDRENS _ DAYTON, Ohio _ The Children's Medical Center has
a hospice-type program for the families of dying children. (Lamb,
Dayton Daily News) 30 inches. WITH PHOTOS

   END-INPATIENT _ DAYTON, Ohio _ Hospice care for patients in the
hospital range from Miami Valley's palliative care program to
arrangements that other hospitals have with Hospice of Dayton.
(Lamb, Dayton Daily News) Less than 10 inches.

   END-LAMB _ DAYTON, Ohio _ Column about some ethical issue(s)
generated from reporting on this series. Perhaps: Assisted suicide,
or Is there even such thing as a ``dignified'' or ``good'' death or
is this another case of the boomer generation trying to control
something beyond its control? (Lamb, Dayton Daily News) 20 inches

   WEDNESDAY, SEPT. 13

   END-MONEYSTRAIN _ DAYTON, Ohio _ Doctors didn't discover Sandra
Lee Hughes' lung cancer until the disease had reached her brain and
paralyzed her legs. At 43, and with two young daughters in her
care, Hughes suddenly had no job and no family support system at a
time when she was facing a terminal disease. She called on her
estranged husband, an unemployed Fairborn resident from whom she
had been separated for six years. He moved her from Alabama to his
home in Fairborn, where family members, including Hughes'
14-year-old daughter, Jennifer, took turns caring for her in a
tiny, ramshackle house. For hours at a time, Jennifer found herself
alone with her mother and, at times, no food to eat. A family
doctor recommended Hospice of Dayton, and soon the agency's home
health aides were there not only to care for Hughes but to make
sure there was enough medical supplies and food in the home.
Hospice never charged the family a penny, but the agency must rely
on donations from the community to help families like Sandra's.
Once she saw that her daughters would be taken care of, Hughes
decided to let go, calling out to Jennifer one night to say
``goodbye.'' (DeBrosse, Dayton Daily News) 25 inches

   WITH PHOTO

   WITH

   END-MONEYSTRAINSIDE _ DAYTON, Ohio _ Tips on how to ease the
financial strain and utilize community resources for families
dealing with the death of a loved one. (DeBrosse, Dayton Daily
News) 10 inches

   WITH

   END-VETS _ DAYTON, Ohio _ Harold Johnson served his country
proudly in Vietnam as an infantry sergeant, only to be exposed by
his own government to a toxic chemical, Agent Orange, that years
later would lead to lung cancer. Johnson, 51, is now in the end
stages of that disease. He says he's no longer bitter about what
happened to him in Vietnam, and that he looks forward to ``meeting
the Lord.'' And he's also grateful to the hospice and palliative
care program at the Dayton VA, which has provided his end-of-life
care free of charge. The VA here wants to get the word out: it
provides a wide array of end-of-life services to eligible veterans,
and at no cost. (DeBrosse, Dayton Daily News) 25 inches. WITH PHOTO

   WITH

   END-PBSSERIES _ DAYTON, Ohio _ Short story explaining the Bill
Moyers'' series, with a how to watch box. (Dayton Daily News)

   WITH

   SERIESBOX _ DAYTON, Ohio _ Furniture about the series, what is
coming up. (Dayton Daily News) Brief.

   THURSDAY, SEPT. 14

   END-CAROL _ DAYTON, Ohio _ Wes Hills first-person story about
his wife Carol's illness and death. (Hill, Dayton Daily News) WITH
PHOTO 115 inches

   WITH

   END-SERIESBOX _ DAYTON, Ohio _ Items about the series. (Dayton
Daily News)

   END OF SERIES

   CHILDREN OF THE CIVIL RIGHTS MOVEMENT PACKAGE

   ATTENTION EDITORS: Atlanta Journal Constitution reporter John
Blake has interviewed several men and women about growing up in the
1950s and '60s as children of the civil rights movement. The people
at the center of the struggle led dramatic, often dangerous, lives.
So, too, did their kids. The children of the movement _ the
offspring of black militants, nonviolent activists and even
segregationist leaders _ are now adults. They have followed many
roads in recent years. Some continue to carry on their parents'
work. Others want only to forget their childhood. Blake profiled
nine of them.

   The story is embargoed until Sunday, Sept. 10, but will move by
Friday evening. PHOTOS are available.

   Stories include:

   CIVILRIGHTS-CHILDREN _ Ericka Brown-Abram thinks she had a
typical childhood. Her mother's friends were killed in police
shootouts. Her family lived under FBI surveillance. She was
constantly shadowed by a bodyguard, even when she ran after the
neighborhood ice cream truck. Brown, 30, the daughter of a Black
Panther Party leader, once thought there was nothing unusual about
growing up in a communal home and attending a grade school where
students read Mao Tse-Tung's Red Book. ``A lot of people had this
swashbuckling idea of the Panthers,'' she said. ``But when you're a
child it all seemed normal.'' Nothing was normal, though, about
growing up in the 1950s and '60s as a child of the civil rights
movement. The people at the center of the struggle led dramatic,
often dangerous, lives. So, too, did their kids. These children of
the movement _ the offspring of black militants, nonviolent
activists and even segregationist leaders _ are now adults. The
Children of the Movement have followed many roads in recent years.
Some continue to carry on their parents' work. Others want only to
forget their childhood. Here are the stories of eight of them.
(Blake, Atlanta Journal-Constitution) 110 inches. WITH PHOTOS.
MOVED FRIDAY.

   WITH THE FOLLOWING PROFILES:

   _ Ericka Brown-Abram _ Daughter of Black Panther Elaine Brown.

   _ Albert Vivian _ Son of Rev. C.T. Vivian, a leader in the
Southern Christian Leadership Conference.

   _ Peggy Wallace _ Daughter of the late Alabama Gov. George
Wallace.

   _ Warith Deen Mohammed _ Son of Elijah Muhammed Sr., leader of
the Nation of Islam.

   Chevara Orrin and Bacardi Jackson _ Daughters of Rev. James
Bevel, a key aide to the Rev. Martin Luther King, Jr.

   Ross Barnett Jr. _ son of Mississippi Gov. Ross Barnett, a
dedicated segregationist.

   END OF PACKAGE

   DIGITAL-CAM _ DAYTON, Ohio _ The first digital still photograph
cameras hit the consumer market a few years ago and digital
camcorders followed more recently. Now it's possible to have two
digital cameras in one. JVC Co. of America has a line of what it
calls Digital DualCams that can record moving video with sound and
still photographs at the same time. (Cummings, Dayton Daily News)
WITH PHOTO. MOVED FRIDAY.

   RADIO _ Once upon a time, the radio was the most important piece
of furniture in most American living rooms. Now those vintage
Crosleys, Zeniths and Atwater Kents that brought us such shows as
Fibber McGee & Molly, Gangbusters and The Lone Ranger are among the
nation's hottest collectibles. (Dayton Daily News) WITH PHOTOS.
MOVED FRIDAY.

   WINE-MAKERS _ GRAND JUNCTION, Colo. _ hat's the biggest myth
when it comes to winemakers? They still stomp grapes with their
feet like the famous episode with Lucille Ball. (Grand Junction
Daily Sentinel) WITH PHOTO. MOVED FRIDAY.

   GLOBAL-WARMING _ Arctic sea ice has thinned by 40 percent in the
last 30 years. This summer, there was open water at the North Pole.
From the Andes to the Alps, mountain glaciers are retreating. And
across North America, from the fire-scorched West to the
drought-parched Southeast, the last year of the millennium has
given millions a summer of discontent. As the signs of a warmer
world grow more apparent, there are some nagging new questions
about ways to prevent it. A new analysis by NASA physicist James
Hansen, one of the first scientists to sound the alarm over global
warming 20 years ago, suggests that industrialized nations
struggling to implement a reduction in carbon dioxide emissions
called for under the proposed 1997 Kyoto Protocol, may be pursuing
the wrong villains in the global greenhouse mystery. (Toner,
Atlanta Journal-Constitution) MOVED FRIDAY.

   ARMY-JOURNALIST _ At a party for his Sunday school class, Jim
McLaughlin decided to play a trivia game, asking his two dozen
guests to jot down something the others didn't know about them. On
his own slip of paper, McLaughlin wrote: ``I did what Gore did in
Vietnam.'' The crowd was stumped. Now, with Al Gore's campaign
publicizing his Vietnam service, the group would probably be able
to guess what McLaughlin meant: He, like Gore, served as an
enlisted Army journalist. (Hendrick, Atlanta Journal-Constitution)
WITH PHOTOS. MOVED FRIDAY.

   TRAVEL

   COXNET TRAVEL _ (EDS: This is the CoxNet Travel page for the
current week. This layout is now available.)

   FAT-CRUISE _ Fighting the battle of the bulge onboard: ``Take
two pairs of pants,'' friends who are cruise veterans advised when
they found out about my plans for a seven-day Caribbean voyage. A
pair you can wear now and one the next size up for after I'd
crossed the sea of indulgence, they said. No way, I replied. Weigh,
they said. Weigh before you go. Weigh after you come back. You'll
be five pounds heavier. And I thought you were supposed to leave
your cares behind on a cruise. Would this be the diary of a
disaster at sea? (AMiller, Atlanta Journal-Constitution) WITH
ILLUSTRATION. MOVED FRIDAY.

   CRUISE-EXPERT _ Three metro Atlanta cruising experts suggest the
best cruises for different types of travelers _ families,
romance-minded, seniors, adventurers, budget-minded. Also,
suggestions of interesting specialty cruises. (Hamilton, Atlanta
Journal-Constitution) MOVED FRIDAY.

   CRUISE-GOING _ Weekly column by Paula Crouch Thrasher of news,
notes and tips. This week: Lots and lots of notes related to
cruises. (Thrasher, Atlanta Journal-Constitution) WITH PHOTOS.
MOVED FRIDAY.

   HOT-ARIZONA _ The first thing that hits you about Phoenix is the
heat. Yes, it's dry heat, whatever that means, but 113 degrees _
the high during a recent trip _ is still hot by any standard. But
there's some good news. The temperatures will soon start to get
cooler, travelers will look for an interesting place to go, and
Phoenix is a nice, affordable destination with more than enough to
do. (Marcano, Dayton Daily News)

   COXNET LIFESTYLES _ (EDS: This is the CoxNet Lifestyles page for
the current week. This layout is now available.)

   COXNET LIFESTYLES 0909: FALL MOVIE PREVIEW: You'd think it was
the turn of the millennium. At least a dozen movies coming this
fall deal with a dark stranger (could it be Satan?), supernatural
oddities or unnatural bloodsuckers. After the box office success
achieved by ``The Sixth Sense'' and ``The Blair Witch Project,''
everybody's lining up to cash in. (Longino, Atlanta
Journal-Constitution) Art includes a 3-column color photo of Jim
Carrey as ``The Grinch,'' a 2-column color photo from the film
``Almost Famous,'' a 18-pica color photo from the film ``The
Contender,'' and a 2-column color photo from the film ``The Legend
of Bagger Vance.''

   END OF PAGE

   FASHION

   AJC's FALL 2000 PREVIEW

   FASHION-DCOM _ Dressing up's back in style as some of Atlanta's
most fashionable dot-commers demonstrate while modeling fall
styles. (Walton, Atlanta Journal-Constitution) MOVED FRIDAY.

   GOLD _ Fashion editor A. Scott Walton extols the virtues of all
things gold in apparel and accessories as we enter the fall fashion
season. (Walton, Atlanta Journal-Constitution) MOVED FRIDAY.

   GOTTAHAVE _ In which we detail must have clothes and accessories
for the fall fashion season. (Johnson, Atlanta
Journal-Constitution) MOVED FRIDAY.

   MAKEUP _ Glamour's returned, so cosmetics are more vibrant and
feminine than in recent years. (Hill, Atlanta Journal-Constitution)
MOVED FRIDAY.

   ENTERTAINMENT/ARTS

   CATS-18YEARS _ Interview with woman who has played on Cats for
18 years. (Erstein, Palm Beach Post) WITH PHOTO. MOVED FRIDAY.

   On Sunday evening, millions of television viewers will tune in
to watch the ``52nd Annual Prime-time Emmy Awards.'' The Academy of
Television Arts and Sciences will hand out winged statuettes in 27
categories to TV's best and brightest. Cox newspapers will have
TV's biggest night covered. There will be stories available
previewing the Emmys from The Atlanta Journal-Constitution, the
Palm Beach Post and the Austin American-Statesman. The Dayton Daily
News will provide live coverage of the broadcast and make a story
available after the show.

   All of the following Emmy stories will be available via the
Budget Tool.

   Any questions, call CoxNet at 404-526-5456

   PALM BEACH POST EMMY PACKAGE:

   FOR SUNDAY

   EMMY-MAIN _ A complete preview and predictions. (Thompson, Palm
Beach Post) 40 inches

   WITH

   EMMY-QA _ A question and answer session with one of the Ernst
and Young accountants. WITH MUG (Thompson, Palm Beach Post) 15
inches

   EMMY-MOMENT - Key Emmy speeches and moments. Brief. (Palm Beach
Post)

   FROM THE AJC

   EMMYS _ An analytical look at tonight's (9/10) Emmys. Is it
Sopranos vs. West Wing? Will & Grace v. the old guard? (Kloer,
Atlanta Journal-Constitution)

   FROM DAYTON

   The Dayton Daily news is planning two, possibly three, live
stories on the Emmy telecast. The stories, written from Dayton,
will be available on the the Budget Tool.

   Stories include:

   EMMY-SHOW _ A wrap-up of the Emmy telecast. (Dempsey, Dayton
Daily News) MOVING AFTER THE SHOW.

   WITH

   EMMY-SIDE _ What was seen, heard at the Emmys. Tidbits and notes
from the show. (Dempsey, Dayton Daily News)

   WESTWING _ This is a tentative story to be written if West Wing
captures several Emmys. Actors Martin Sheen, Rob Lowe and Allison
Janney has ties to Dayton. (Dempsey, Dayton Daily News) TENTATIVE.

   FROM AUSTIN

   EMMY0910 _ We predict who is going to take home the gold.
(Holloway, Austin American-Statesman) 35 inches

   END OF EMMY COVERAGE

   MOVIES

   CROWE _ Interview with writer-director Cameron Crowe (''Jerry
Maguire''), whose latest movie ``Almost Famous'' is an
autobiographical movie that fictionalizes his own experience, as a
15-year-old precocious journalist, going on the road with an
upcoming band to write a piece for Rolling Stone. (Murray, Atlanta
Journal-Constitution) MOVED FRIDAY.

   MUSIC

   LORETTA-LYNN _ Profile of Loretta Lynn, from her Nashville dude
ranch/home, right before her annual homecoming show. Her new album
comes out Sept. 12, and a second autobiography is due as well.
(Longino, Atlanta Journal-Constitution) MOVED FRIDAY.

   WEBRADIO _ iTurf is a Web site aimed at teens. The company that
runs the site has launched a new radio component that is live
weekdays from 1 p.m.-1 a.m., with a chat function that hooks up
listeners to each other and the DJ. Listeners can discuss the music
as it plays. Along with Soundbreak.com and a couple of other sites,
this represents a growing trend in live, DJ-hosted Internet-only
radio. (Drennen, Atlanta Journal-Constitution) MOVED FRIDAY.

   COXNET BUDGET INFORMATION

   This budget moves daily through the week, then on Saturday at 2
p.m. and 6 p.m. EDT and afterwards as necessary based on news
developments. If stories will move after 8 p.m., an ETA will be
given. All times are Eastern unless otherwise noted.

   PHOTOS, LAYOUTS and GRAPHICS

   Features, business and op-ed material on this budget is
available exclusively through the Budget Tool, which brings into
your database the story with attached layout and graphics.

   Regarding all other material: Stories that have photos, graphics
or page layouts will be posted on the Cox Server in folders
matching the category and slug. (Exception: Bureau photos are
available only through the Atlanta Location, Washington Bureau
desk, slugged to match the story.) Pages marked as CoxNet pages are
also available through Locations in the WAN desk of the AJC's
database.
